I'm a little confused by this Scope, Scope.Builder, NameScope, NameScope.Builder relationships. It seems like a lot of abstraction that can be simplified, but perhaps I'm mistaken.

I was imagining a single class, Scope, with something like this:

public final class Scope {
   ...
   // All the state needed for a Scope
   private final Graph graph;
   private final String name;  // "fully qualified name", i.e., path from root to here with slashes
   private final Map<String, int> opNames;  // Map from op-name (ignoring scope name prefix) to count
   private final Map<String, int> subNames;  // Map from sub-scope name to count
  
   // Unfortunate additional state needed for withOpName.
   // null to use the operation name as the node name
   private String opName;
}

And then:

  • new Scope would set all fields (name to "", opName to null, the maps to newly allocated maps)
  • withSubScope would do the name as new Scope except set name to this.name + "/" + name
  • withOpName would copy all the fields of the "parent" Scope (so that the count maps are shared), but set opName differently

I think doing so will make the scope code easier to follow as there will be fewer layers to navigate through.
Thoughts?
